title: Refraction - semicircular slab and critical angle

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Light rays from two identical lasers <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> pass through air and are incident at right angles on the surface of a semicircular slab of transparent material, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The critical angle of incidence <math alttext="theta sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mtext>c</mtext></msub></math> for the slab material at a boundary with air is indicated as well.

(a) On Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, draw the paths of all reflected and refracted rays that result from the rays from lasers <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> that are incident upon the left edge of the semicircular piece. Label each ray as either a reflected ray or a refracted ray, AND whether the ray comes from Laser <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> or Laser <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. For example, “Reflected − <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>” would be an appropriate label for a reflected ray due to Laser <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>.

The critical angle of incidence <math alttext="theta sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mtext>c</mtext></msub></math> for the slab material at a boundary with air is indicated as well.

(a) On Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, draw the paths of all reflected and refracted rays that result from the rays from lasers <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> that are incident upon the left edge of the semicircular piece. Label each ray as either a reflected ray or a refracted ray, AND whether the ray comes from Laser <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> or Laser <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. For example, “Reflected − <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>” would be an appropriate label for a reflected ray due to Laser <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>.

(b) Derive an expression for the speed of light in the slab material. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="theta sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mtext>c</mtext></msub></math> and physical constants, as appropriate.

It is later determined that the slab material has a refractive index <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi></math> equal to <math alttext="1.33" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.33</mn></math>. One of the lasers is moved around so that its beam remains incident on Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> at the center of the straight edge of the slab, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The angle of incidence changes as the laser is moved around.
(c) On the axes in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the sine of the angle of refraction <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> for the laser beam in air at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> as a function of the sine of the angle of incidence <math alttext="theta sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math> of the beam inside the slab at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>. Explicitly label the coordinates for any maxima or nonzero minima.

(d) Indicate a feature or aspect of the graph you drew in part (c) that is either consistent or not consistent with a feature or aspect of the rays you drew in part (a). Explicitly state whether the features or aspects you indicate are consistent, and justify your claim that they are or are not consistent.
